title: 2015896 - GEOMATICA BASICA
text:
ğŸ“‘ Course Brief
Focus: the focus of this course is introduce concepts, methods and tecniques used in geoinformation disciplines.
How: reading, learning by doing and writing


ğŸ¯ Learning Objectives

Understand the usefulness of geospatial data for supporting agronomy.
Internalize basic concepts about geodesy, cartography, GIS, remote sensing, and geostatistics.
Be able to apply geospatial techniques for data collection, processing, visualization and analysis.
Develop critical spatial thinking.


Select Academic Year/Term:

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 9Digital elevation models
text:
Definitions
What is a DEM?
A digital elevation model (DEM) is a general term representing ground elevation above sea level. In a DEM, all surface features (trees, buildings, bridges, etc.) are stripped away, and only the bare earth is represented.
A DEM shows: - Topographic information (height asl) - Slopes - River beds - Hills, valleys, furrows and ridges



What is a DTM?
A digital terrain model (DTM) is a layer â€˜on topâ€™ of the DEM. It will show additional information that the bare earth DEM might not represent, including things like:

Breaklines are changes in the terrain on a surface
Manmade and natural linear features of the bare earth terrain, such as roads, railway tracks, flood defences, pipelines, coastlines, or rivers.




What is a DSM?
A digital surface model (DSM) is a type of terrain that includes all features above the bare earth - both natural and man-made. It will include ground features such as buildings, infrastructure, trees, and vegetation. The layer will represent the height of all these features above the ground on which they stand.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 9Digital elevation models
text:
Uses of topography data
Uses of DEMs & DTMs
DEMs and DTMs help us understand the â€˜naturalâ€™ shape of the earthâ€™s surface - without the â€˜distractionâ€™ of buildings, trees, or other infrastructure.
Both are especially useful for things like: - Hydrology - Terrain form - Slope stability - Simulations
Uses of DSM
DSMs show you both ground elevation and the height of everything above it. This allows you to understand how ground features interact with one another and the bare earth.
DSMs are useful for things like: - Radio frequency planning - Private networks - Emergency planning - Line of sight planning - Smart city mapping

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 9Digital elevation models
text:
Data acquisition
Tecniques
Elevation data can be measured by: 1. field surveying 2. photogrammetry 3. cartographic digitization 4. airborne laser scanning
Field surveys
